questions.question_text:
You have a Windows 10 device that has two local users named User1 and User2.

User1 performs the tasks shown in the following table.

//IMG//


The results of which tasks will be visible when User2 signs in to the device?

discussion.content:

Should be C. Task3 and Task4 only
C is the answer

Should be C. Task3 and Task4 only

questions.question_text:
You have a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 11.

You plan to change a registry setting on Computer1.

You need to ensure that you can revert to the previous registry setting if the change causes an issue on Computer1. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B and D

Correct answers are B and D

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have computers that run Windows 11.

You plan to configure the security settings on each computer to meet the following requirements:

• Protect files against ransomware.
• Ensure that affected data can be recovered if a ransomware attack occurs.

What should you use for each requirement? To answer, drag the appropriate features to the correct requirements. Each feature may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

choices.B: Local Users and Groups in Computer Management
choices.C: Email & accounts in the Settings app

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I think the correct answer is A. The other options do not meet the goal.

questions.question_text:
You have a workgroup computer that runs Windows 10.

You need to set the minimum password length to 12 characters.

What should you use?

You are a network administrator at your company.
The company uses an application that checks for network connectivity to a server by sending a ping request to the IPv6 address of the server. If the server replies, the application loads.
A user cannot open the application.
You manually send the ping request from the computer of the user and the server does not reply. You send the ping request from your computer and the server replies.
You need to ensure that the ping request works from the user's computer.
Which Windows Defender firewall rule is a possible cause of the issue?

choices.B: File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out)
choices.D: File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-In)

comments.content: In ping the packets are walking to the both sides

Just tested it in the lab: when blocking inbound icmpv6 the client is still able to ping the server, it's just incoming pings that don't get answered.
Thus the correct answer is B
Incorrect, answer is D, I have just tested this, please stop sharing incorrect information

discussion.content: Correct answer is B. The inbound rule will have no effect on the pings from the user's computer, but an outbound rule set to block will stop the ping leaving. I've just tested this.

Answer is D. The server can respond to other computers but not the users computer which suggests a setting needs to be changed on the users computer. The server does not reply does not mean that it did not receive it. The reply just was not registered by the users computer. Hence the incoming rule.

comments.content: If the link referenced is correct then the answer to this question is D. To enable ping, you need to set an INBOUND ICMP exception rule in the firewall, somehow.

You are right that the issue is on the client computer, but choosing the wrong rule...
1. client is using the echo-request-out rule
2. server is using the echo-request-in rule
3. client is using the echo-reply-in rule
(B)
Yes and ping works from other computer !

discussion.content: At first I thought the answer was D, but after digging a bit deeper and going to this page: https://kb.iu.edu/d/aopy it definitely seems like B. ECHO Requests In is to allow other machines to be able to ping you, it is turned off to prevent certain attacks like DDoS. ECHO Request Out allow you to send those ping requests out.

Selected Answer: D
For me is D. I think if it was B it would not have context to the specification in the question that the server responds to other clients.

Selected Answer: D
IN rule affects ping

comments.content:
The other options are incorrect because they are not related to allowing incoming ICMPv6 traffic, which is required for the ping request to work from the user's computer to the server.

Answer A, File and Printer Sharing (NB-Datagram-In), is responsible for allowing inbound NetBIOS datagram traffic, which is used for file and printer sharing between computers on a network.

Answer B, File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out), is responsible for allowing outgoing ICMPv6 traffic, which includes ping requests, from the computer to the network.

Answer C, File and Printer Sharing (NB-Datagram-Out), is responsible for allowing outbound NetBIOS datagram traffic, which is used for file and printer sharing between computers on a network.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D. File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-In).

The issue may be caused by a Windows Defender firewall rule that is blocking the ping request from the user's computer to the server. The fact that the ping request works from your computer indicates that the server is properly configured to respond to ping requests.

The File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-In) rule is responsible for allowing incoming ICMPv6 traffic, which includes ping requests, from the network to the computer. If this rule is not enabled on the user's computer, it may be blocking the ping request to the server.

By enabling the File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-In) rule, you allow the user's computer to receive incoming ping requests which should resolve the issue.
The possible cause of the issue is option B: "File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out)". chatgpt

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

B (tested).

Bear in mind you are pinging the server from the computer in the question and not getting a reply. That does not mean the server is getting the initial ping and the reply is being blocked by the sending computer. I tried each of the below, resetting firewall rules between each change.

Standard behavior (no outbound or inbound rules enabled, no inbound ICMP rule enabled): you can ping out and get a reply, you can't ping in from another computer to that one.
Enabling outbound allowing ICMP: does nothing, same effect as default behavior
Enabling inbound allowing ICMP: allows another computer to ping this one
Enable inbound rule blocking ICMP: blocks only inbound pings, outbound still go out and get replies 
Changing Outbound rule to blocking ICMP: General failure message. Ping fails.

So it's B, if you're just looking at the computer sending pings. Specifically, outbound ICMP has been blocked. Disabling that rule should allow the pings again, putting it back to default behavior.

Selected Answer: D
I have tested between two Windows 10 client VM's and again with Windows Server 2012 and a Windows 10 client ONLY THE INBOUND RULE AFFECTS PING REQUESTS when both computers are on the same network!!!!! I'm not yet sure when Outbound comes into play but I'm assuming between different networks. However the question is misleading the change is needed by the SERVER not the CLIENT. In my testing allowing incoming requests by the firewall allows to other computer to request ping. In this case the client can not ping the server so a change or addition in the inbound rule by the server is required. Again this information based on my test with two Win 10 IPv4 firewall rules.

comments.content:
Notice: “the server does not reply”. That is, the server is not responding why? Either the user's machine is not sending requests (general failure) or the server is not returning replies (request timed out).

But the question remains: “You need to ensure that the ping request works from the user's computer.”. Here, what is expected to be known is to ensure that the user's machine is sending requests.

B. File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out)

discussion.content: I don't understand why it says "Echo Request In". Shouldn't it be "Echo Reply In"?
windows firewall by default dont block 'out', but block 'in'... Now i understand why 'd' is correct...

How can you really know with this little bit of information. the other computer pinged succesfull. But if my outbound is blocking then the server won't receive a ping, but when it's is inboud your computer can't receive the ping back.

Resposta D está correta:

Regras de entrada
Quando você instala o sistema operacional Windows pela primeira vez, o Windows Defender Firewall bloqueia todo o tráfego de entrada não solicitado. Para permitir um certo tipo de tráfego de entrada não solicitado, você deve criar uma regra de entrada que descreva esse tráfego. 

Regras de saída
O Windows Defender Firewall permite todo o tráfego de saída, a menos que uma regra o bloqueie. As regras de saída permitem ou negam explicitamente o tráfego originário de um computador que corresponda aos critérios de uma regra.


https://learn.microsoft.com/pt-br/training/modules/explore-microsoft-defender/6-explain-windows-defender-firewall-advanced-security

Outbound rules
Windows Defender Firewall allows all outbound traffic unless a rule blocks it. Outbound rules explicitly allow or deny traffic originating from a computer that matches a rule’s criteria. For example, you can configure a rule to explicitly block outbound traffic to a computer by IP address through the firewall, but allow the same traffic for other computer

https://learn.microsoft.com/pt-br/training/modules/explore-microsoft-defender/6-explain-windows-defender-firewall-advanced-security

Selected Answer: B
Note those statements in the question
* “If the server replies” and “the server does not reply” - Server issue (inbound ICMP network traffic)
* “The company uses an application that checks for network connectivity to a server by sending a ping request to the IPv6 address of the server.” - user's perspective (inbound ICMP network traffic)
* "You need to ensure that the ping request works from the user's computer.” - FROM THE USER’S COMPUTER

The real scenario: the server is not responding to requests or responses from/to user request. BUT we need to make sure that the ping request works from the user’s computer.

comments.content:
We need to make sure that the ping request works from the user’s computer.

B. File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out)

Definition of Inbound ICMP Rule - This type of rule allows ICMP requests and responses to be sent and received by computers on the network.

Link definition: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/windows-firewall/create-an-inbound-icmp-rule#:~:text=This%20type%20of%20rule%20allows%20ICMP%20requests%20and%20responses%20to%20be%20sent%20and%20received%20by%20computers%20on%20the%20network.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
If you read the provided link you will see it is B. https://www.howtogeek.com/howto/windows-vista/allow-pings-icmp-echo-request-through-your-windows-vista-firewall/

Selected Answer: D
It's D. 
From user testing and explanations here in the comments, you can see that the inbound ICMPv6 Rule is what prevents the echo response. The outbound rule for ICMPv6 echo requests doesn't somehow allow the inbound path to be open - the inbound rule is the problem.

comments.content: But all resources say INBOUND, though.
This is a good arguement.

discussion.content: Assuming we're talking about firewall settings on the user's computer, B is the only possible choice. A and C use a different protocol, so they are automatically eliminated. The scenario indicates that the user's computer sends an ICMPv6 echo request to the server, and the server sends back an echo reply. So it's echo request going out, and echo reply coming back in. But none of the answers have incoming echo reply. B is the only one.

If the communication is initiated from your end(outbound traffic allowed) you will receive the response. No need to worry about the inbound rule, that only pertains to you not wanting to respond to pings that are not initiated from other devices.

comments.content: In* D -
Thus, choice B

The inbound rule will have no effect on the pings from the user's computer, but an outbound rule set to block will stop the ping leaving. I've just tested this.

comments.content: ICMPv6-In is open by default

discussion.content: The initiator of the ping is the usercomputer. You need only to open the firewall ICMPv6-Out. Because the usercomputer is the initiator of the ping traffic. opening the ICMPv6-In is not nessesary

If the server reply from another computer - it cant be File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-In) it then must be outgoing from the users computer.

I vote for File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out).

B.

so answer is 100% B:

comments.content:
Totally agree with you

If the problem was the client (which is strange because the default is ALLOW OUTBOUND), then from WF of the client, I would check the File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out) from the OUTBOUND RULES

If the problem was the server (which most probably is) because it explicitly needs to allow File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-In) from INBOUND RULES which seems to be allowed but maybe filtered not to include the IP/Subnet of the client

Both answers are good, but the question is too fuzzy. They should have added more information

discussion.content: Honestly, this question is stuffed. It could be either B or D depending whether you are talking about the firewall on the client computer or the server. Yes, the answer could be B if the client is blocking outbound - but it's enabled by default, why the heck would it be blocking outbound? It could be D because the server could have IP filtering enabled and maybe the techie testing it from his/her computer is in the allowed list of IPs.... I'd like to know what Microsoft reckon the answer is for the purpose of their test.

comments.content:
"outbound is already allowed" where can I find that in the question?
The server replied to another computer, it means the server is working find.
To me, it seems like the server did not get the request so the answer should be B.

discussion.content: Correct is D, outbound is already allowed.

The answer "D" is correct. If an Outbound BLOCK was enabled, this would have resulted in "General Failure" in CMD (meaning you can't Ping OUT) but that is not what the scenario states (that an explicit failure happened). The ping from the End User is able to go through (since no explicit error message/General Failure) but NO REPLY/Echo Request was received from the server which must mean Inbound packet is blocked.

Try it out yourself on 2x Workgroup clients and ping one to the other:
1. First Verifying Ping (ICMP) works between the two clients
2. Then Disable (turned on to ALLOW Echo Request by default) the INBOUND File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request - ICMP In) Firewall Rule which will result in CMD stating "Request timed out"/NO REPLY from the other client. KISS
The correct Answer is "D"

Pay attention to: "You send the ping request from your computer and the server replies."
This means that the firewall on the server end is configured correctly and we must look at the users computer for the problem.

This must mean that the outbound (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out) rule on the user's computer is not allowing the ping to leave the computer, resulting in a "General failure." when you ping a device in the network.

The inbound (Echo Request ICMPv6-In) rule controls if the users computer is able to receive a ping request from other systems, this is not the question.

So the answer should be: B. File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request ICMPv6-Out)

I agree with Haribo112 .
And;
"You need to ensure that the ping request works from the user's computer"
I think they want to hear the OUT option

comments.content: This is one of those famous trick questions from Microsoft and you are absolutely right, it could actually be B or D being the problem. Given the clues in the question, I believe B is right, since pinging to the server works from another computer, so it seems they are leading you away from the server being the issue in this case. If Microsoft said: both computers are on the same subnet, this question would be a slam dunk for B.

discussion.content: Both the ICMP In and Out rules could be wrong. If the user's machine has the outbound ping blocked, the server will not respond. But if the server has the inbound rule scoped so that it does not apply to the user's machine, the same behaviour will show.

comments.content:
Open your Windows Defender in Control Panel and go to Advanced. Notice under "View and Create firewall rules the statement: "By default, inbound connections are blocked unless they match a rule that allows them, and outbound connections are allowed unless they match a rule that blocks them.
The user that is not able to load the program is not seeing the ping response from the server, not because he has deliberately set a rule, but because he has not deliberately allowed a rule that would alter the default action. The Echo Request (ICMPv6-In) rule that is blocked by default needs to be allowed. Answer is D.

discussion.content:
I think the answer is B. Here's my reasoning: 
The question says "If the server replies, the application loads. A user cannot open the application".
For me this means that the server never gets the signal... as in outgoing to the server from the computer. 

Since the ping works from another computer, it doesn't seem like the problem comes from receiving part of the computer but from the outgoing part. 

So I'm inclined to go with Beitran, JairoJunior_br and mark491. 
B
Once again, people saying two different answers in the comments. What is the correct answer?

The inbound rule handles a ping request from other computers. This is the rule that is used by the server, and that one is working. So it already must go wrong on the users pc when sending the request --> Outbound

comments.content: Correct, and quite easy to test.

comments.content: Windows Defender Firewall default is enable outbound and disable inbound.

discussion.content:

It shows how to enable ping, creating a INBOUND rule.

To allow inbound Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) network traffic, use the Windows Defender Firewall with Advanced Security node in the Group Policy Management MMC snap-in to create firewall rules. This type of rule allows ICMP requests and responses to be SENT and RECEIVED by computers on the network.
it is D - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/windows-firewall/create-an-inbound-icmp-rule
